natural problem: Consider the polynomials  \[f(x)=1-12x+3x^2-4x^3+5x^4\] and \[g(x)=3-2x-6x^3+9x^4.\] Find $c$ such that the polynomial $f(x)+cg(x)$ has degree 3.
natural solution: The polynomial $f(x)+cg(x)$ will have degree 3 exactly when the $x^4$ terms cancel and the $x^3$ terms do not. The $x^4$ term of $f(x)+cg(x)$ is \[5x^4+c(9x^4)=(5+9c)x^4.\]This is zero when $c=-5/9$. If $c=-5/9$, the $x^3$ term is   \[-4x^3+c(-6x^3)=(-4-6\cdot -5/9)x^3=-\frac{2}{3}x^3\neq0.\]Therefore there is only one solution $c=\boxed{-\frac{5}{9}}$.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x c :: real and f g :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f x = 1 - 12 * x + 3 * (x powr 2) - 4 * (x powr 3) + 5 * (x powr 4)"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. g x = 3 - 2 * x - 6 * (x powr 3) + 9 * (x powr 4)"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. f x + c * g x = 0 * (x powr 4) + a * (x powr 3) + b * (x powr 2) + c * x + d"
shows  "c = -5 / 9"

If $c=-5/9$, the $x^3$ term is   \[-4x^3+c(-6x^3)=(-4-6\cdot -5/9)x^3=-\frac{2}{3}x^3\neq0.\]Therefore there is only one solution $c=\boxed{-\frac{5}{9}}$.
 *)

a_0.informal problem: Consider two functions $f$ and $g$ defined as $f(x) = 1 - 12x + 3x^2 - 4x^3 + 5x^4$ and $g(x) = 3 - 2x - 6x^3 + 9x^4$. If the function $f(x) + cg(x)$ equals a polynomial of the form $0x^4 + ax^3 + bx^2 + cx + d$, find the value of $c$. The final answer is $-\frac{5}{9}$.
